title: Click jacking

profile.name: Factlink
profile.about: Share your knowledge with the world.

vulnerability_information:
Vulnerability description
Clickjacking (User Interface redress attack, UI redress attack, UI redressing) is a malicious technique of tricking a Web user into clicking on something different from what the user perceives they are clicking on, thus potentially revealing confidential information or taking control of their computer while clicking on seemingly innocuous web pages. 


Affected items
Web Server 

The impact of this vulnerability
The impact depends on the affected web application.
vulnerability_information_html:
Vulnerability description
Clickjacking (User Interface redress attack, UI redress attack, UI redressing) is a malicious technique of tricking a Web user into clicking on something different from what the user perceives they are clicking on, thus potentially revealing confidential information or taking control of their computer while clicking on seemingly innocuous web pages.

Affected items
Web Server

The impact of this vulnerability
The impact depends on the affected web application.

activities.message:
Issue description
It might be possible for a web page controlled by an attacker to load the content of this response within an iframe on the attacker's page. This may enable a "clickjacking" attack, in which the attacker's page overlays the target application's interface with a different interface provided by the attacker. By inducing victim users to perform actions such as mouse clicks and keystrokes, the attacker can cause them to unwittingly carry out actions within the application that is being targeted. This technique allows the attacker to circumvent defenses against cross-site request forgery, and may result in unauthorized actions.
activities.markdown_message:
Issue description
It might be possible for a web page controlled by an attacker to load the content of this response within an iframe on the attacker's page. This may enable a "clickjacking" attack, in which the attacker's page overlays the target application's interface with a different interface provided by the attacker. By inducing victim users to perform actions such as mouse clicks and keystrokes, the attacker can cause them to unwittingly carry out actions within the application that is being targeted. This technique allows the attacker to circumvent defenses against cross-site request forgery, and may result in unauthorized actions.

activities.message: The lack of X-Frame-Options does not always indicate that a security vulnerability is present. This is an optional header that is only necessary on endpoints where there UI is rendered to invoke state changing actions. We recommend reading this informative post by David Ross: https://plus.google.com/u/0/+DavidRossX/posts/jVrtTRd5yKP
activities.markdown_message: The lack of X-Frame-Options does not always indicate that a security vulnerability is present. This is an optional header that is only necessary on endpoints where there UI is rendered to invoke state changing actions. We recommend reading this informative post by David Ross: https://plus.google.com/u/0/+DavidRossX/posts/jVrtTRd5yKP

activities.message: r u agree with me it is vul or not
activities.markdown_message: r u agree with me it is vul or not

activities.message: will i get HOF or anything..

We cannot totally avoid this. A large part of our application runs in an iframe, and is inherently 'vulnerable' to this as it needs the functionality. However, we do not need it for our main site, and will close it for as much routes as possible. When resolved you will get HOF.
activities.markdown_message: We cannot totally avoid this. A large part of our application runs in an iframe, and is inherently 'vulnerable' to this as it needs the functionality. However, we do not need it for our main site, and will close it for as much routes as possible. When resolved you will get HOF.

activities.message:
We fixed this bug by setting X-Frame-Options where possible. As stated before, the part of the site which has to run in a frame doesn't have these of course. You can inspect the entire solution here:

https://github.com/Factlink/factlink-core/pull/24
activities.markdown_message:
We fixed this bug by setting X-Frame-Options where possible. As stated before, the part of the site which has to run in a frame doesn't have these of course. You can inspect the entire solution here:

https://github.com/Factlink/factlink-core/pull/24
